data.source: Quantitative online survey via ISO-certified online access panel
data.wave_or_subset: Single cross-sectional wave collected March 19–23, 2020; adults (18+) in Germany who reported not being infected
data.access_details: Data collected by an ISO-certified panel provider responsible for programming and recruitment; dataset access or request process not stated
data.notes: All questions were mandatory; initial completes N=1300; after data cleansing (removing respondents who took less than seven minutes) N=1242 remained; online-representative by gender, age, and federal state; age range 18–74 (limited by panel provider); coverage of all German federal states; Likert-scale items throughout; some behavioral items adapted from Universität Duisburg-Essen survey (Teufel 2020).

method.description: A cross-sectional online survey of adults in Germany measured risk perception (cognitive and affective dimensions and psychometric characteristics), fear, coping strategies (problem-focused and emotion-focused), related behaviors, trust in institutions, and emergency food preparedness during March 19–23, 2020. Data were collected via an ISO-certified panel provider, cleaned by excluding very short completions, and analyzed using descriptive statistics, significance testing for group differences, and correlations.
steps: Design questionnaire covering risk perception (likelihood and psychometric dimensions), fear, coping (German Ways of Coping Scale adaptation), behaviors, trust, and food preparedness.
Program and field the survey via an ISO-certified online access panel to adults (18+) in Germany (self-reported not infected).
Collect responses between March 19 and March 23, 2020 (N=1300).
Clean data by removing respondents who completed the survey in under seven minutes, yielding N=1242.
Compute descriptive statistics (means, SDs, percentages) for all items and scales.
Assess internal consistency of coping scales (Cronbach’s alpha).
Conduct group comparisons (e.g., by gender, age groups, federal states) with significance testing (p-values reported).
Compute correlations for relationships with age where relevant.
method.models: Descriptive statistics (means, percentages); significance testing for group differences (p-values reported); correlations (e.g., Pearson r).
method.outcome_variable: Risk perception ratings (likelihood of infection for self, family/friends, general); fear measures; coping scales (problem-focused and emotion-focused); specific preventive behaviors; trust in institutions; days of food supplies and stockpiling behaviors; reasons for food stockpiling.
method.independent_variables: Age; gender; federal state; urbanicity (population size of place of residence).

results.summary: Adults in Germany perceived higher COVID-19 infection risk for family/friends than for themselves. Older respondents estimated lower infection risk than younger ones, while women reported higher worry and fear than men. COVID-19 was widely viewed as a new, global disaster yet as controllable and reducible. Coping was predominantly problem-focused, with respondents following expert advice and avoiding rash actions; emotion-focused coping was less endorsed. Many reported increased hand hygiene and avoidance of public places and transport. Trust was highest in medical institutions and experts, followed by companies and politics. At least half reported food supplies for 10–11 days; about 42% bought more food than usual, primarily to reduce shopping frequency and prepare for possible quarantine.
